contrib-group.aff: 1Creighton University School of Medicine, Omaha, NE, USA

author-notes.corresp: Roger A. Brumback, MD, Creighton University School of Medicine, Omaha, NE 68131, USA Email: rogerbrumback@hotmail.com

abstract.p: “Publish or perish” is the time-honored “principle” for academicians who race to accumulate lines under the “publications” section of a curriculum vitae. The original intent of publication—to inform others of findings and further scientific knowledge—has been corrupted by factors including (1) exponential growth of journals and the journal industry, fueled in part by intrusion of the Internet into all aspects of academic life; and (2) adoption of journal metrics (rather than written content) as the measure of scientific quality. The proprietary Thomson Reuters Impact Factor is the most pernicious metric, having caused editors and publishers to change editorial practices to boost the number. At the same time, gullible administrators and government agencies have been persuaded that metrics for the journal in which materials are published can be used as a measure of the worth of individual investigators (and institutions) and their research efforts: simple numbers can be substituted for the burdensome effort required to read and assess research quality. Thus, granting of research funds, awarding of academic rank and tenure, and determination of salaries (including bonus payments) have become tied to manipulable journal metrics rather than the significance or quality of reported research. Therefore, it is no wonder that the integrity of science is more often being questioned. How should a young investigator approach the “publish or perish” dilemma? Performing sound research and preparing optimal materials for publication must remain the overriding goals: properly articulate the question addressed by the study; thoroughly document all methods and case information; carefully describe results including any conflicting or negative findings; discuss the importance of the findings along with how the results address the initial question and whether findings refute or confirm previous studies; prepare properly cited bibliographic references; list all author contributions, potential conflicts of interest, financial support, and required ethical approvals; and provide a catchy title and an abstract containing sufficient information that other investigators perusing scientific indices will be enticed to read the published article. Submit the completed manuscript to the most appropriate journal based on that journal’s previously published content and relevance to the field of study regardless of journal metrics. On publication, notify investigators in the same field to ask for their comments on the work. Thus, an individual will become known for the quality of his or her work product and the worshiping of publication metrics will be unnecessary.

body.p:
Anyone who has read the Journal of Child Neurology over the years since its founding1 in 1986 will recognize that I have utilized the Impact Factor values produced by the Institute for Scientific Information (now a part of Thomson Reuters) in a number of notes and commentaries describing the state of the journal.1
–4 I was even able to purchase in the late 1990s at considerable expense some of the database information from the Institute for Scientific Information (ISI) that allowed me to compare the Journal of Child Neurology to other journals in its field.2 Figure 1 shows the trend of the Impact Factor values over the life of the Journal of Child Neurology obtained from the various ISI and Thomson Reuters publications and online databases. SAGE Publications, the publisher of the Journal of Child Neurology, uses the annual Thomson Reuters Impact Factor number in their advertisements for the journal (for example on the website http://jcn.sagepub.com/). Separately, I have used the Thomson Reuters Web of Knowledge database to obtain data related to article retractions for a recent editorial commentary5 in the other journal for which I serve as editor-in-chief (the Journal of Evidence-Based Complementary & Alternative Medicine [JEBCAM]).

caption.p: Thomson Reuters Impact Factor values for the Journal of Child Neurology from the years 1988 to 2011 (data from ISI and Thomson Reuters publications including Journal Citation Reports).

body.p:
In 2007, Rossner and colleagues prepared an editorial (simultaneously published in the 3 highly regarded journals of the Rockefeller University Press: Journal of Cell Biology,6 Journal of Experimental Medicine,7 and Journal of General Physiology8) that questioned the validity of the calculations that produce the Thomson Reuters Impact Factor values. I then published an editorial in 2008 indicating my concern that scientists are acquiescing to the dictatorial whims of administrators and bureaucrats who find it easier to classify and rank scientific achievements by using a simple number (such as the Thomson Reuters Impact Factor value) rather than by evaluating research for its true worth through actually reading the article and assessing the science involved.9 Thomson Reuters prepared a response10 that was published in the Journal of Child Neurology later that same year. With all the ongoing commentary concerning the Thomson Reuters Impact Factor,11
–25 I prepared another editorial on the topic for the Journal of Child Neurology26 and a letter to the editor published in Epidemiology.27 Meanwhile, the exclusivity of the Thomson Reuters databases as ranking metrics has been supplanted by the appearance of metrics produced by Google Scholar and by Elsevier SciVerse for the ranking of published articles28 (although the Thomson Reuters Impact Factor remains the “500 pound gorilla in the room”).

On June 4, 2012, I was surprised to receive an email from Google Scholar Alerts notifying me that there was a new article appearing in the journal Scientometrics that cited 2 of my publications26,27 concerning the Thomson Reuters Impact Factor. Clicking on the supplied link in that email quickly led me to an article29 by Jacso that had just been published on May 31, 2012, on the SpringerLink Online First website. (Of note, I also subscribe to the Thomson Reuters Web of Knowledge Citation Alerts but did not receive a notification from that source about the Jacso publication29 until August 22, 2012, presumably because the Web of Knowledge provides such alerts only after the official publication issue appears.) Upon reading that online article,29 it became apparent to me that the tone was not at all flattering (I was characterized as one of “fellow gun-slingers with excessively demonizing and bellicose vocabulary . . . making belligerent statements”) and that the article29 was prepared in what journalistic slang would best be characterized as a “hit piece” (definition: “an attempt to turn public opinion against someone/something through the appearance of objective reporting or editorializing”; http://www.dictionaryslang.com/hit-piece). The author (a master of words as befits his law school education) was a classic demagogue in using ad hominen attacks and inappropriately mixing into the article his own personal political hatred of the Republican Party in the United States. The vitriol in the Jacso article29 and the rejection of my response sent for publication to Scientometrics (apparently the author Jacso was the decision maker for the editor of Scientometrics with criticisms such as, “There is no specific comment related to the dozen of problems discussed in my commentary”) served only to underscore the zealotry of those who worship at the altar of the Thomson Reuters Impact Factor values.9 Interestingly, Jacso in his article29 did not cite my article9 “Worshiping False Idols . . .” in which I questioned such passionate devotion to this journal metric.

Scientific worth should never be gauged by some statistical value, but rather evaluated for its true quality, a concern that is shared by many.12,14,19,20,30,31 The fallacy of relying on ranking numbers such as the Thomson Reuters Impact Factor values rather than the evaluation of the quality of published material can be illustrated by an example of 3 articles published in the year 1998. Roach and colleagues32 produced an article titled “Tuberous Sclerosis Complex Consensus Conference: Revised Clinical Diagnostic Criteria” that was published in the Journal of Child Neurology. This article provided definitive diagnostic criteria for clinical evaluation and research investigation of tuberous sclerosis complex and continues to be used and cited, since diagnostic testing for mutations in the involved disease genes—TSC1 (gene product: hamartin) and TSC2 (gene product: tuberin)—is burdensome and expensive. In that same year in the Journal of Child Neurology, Sheth and Jaynes33 described a teenage girl with spinal cord symptoms due to a mass lesion identified on imaging studies who after refusing biopsy was treated with corticosteroids resulting in nearly complete resolution of her problem. While an interesting case, the article by Sheth and Jaynes33 did not add any significantly new knowledge to the world’s scientific literature (and thus has never been cited, until now). Since both articles appeared in the same journal in the same year, a mindless bureaucracy only interested in number rankings would rate them equally, assigning each article the same Thomson Reuters Impact Factor value associated with the Journal of Child Neurology (Figure 1). Of course, this is absurd, since even a superficial reading of the 2 articles would readily discern the difference in their importance. A secondary problem with using number values is what number should be assigned to the authors of the important Roach et al32 contribution? Since the Thomson Reuters Impact Factor values for the Journal of Child Neurology have varied year to year (as shown in Figure 1), should the Roach et al32 article be assigned the 0.929 value of its year of publication (1998), the 1.134 value of the year 2000 (which was the end of the impact of that article on the Thomson Reuters Impact Factor calculation), or a 1.748 value for the year 2011. As is obvious, there would be nearly an 80% swing in the numerical importance assigned to the work of Roach and his colleagues32 depending on which Thomson Reuters Impact Factor value is chosen.

To complete this example, a third article that appeared in 1998 was published in the prominent British journal The Lancet (published by Elsevier B.V.), written by Wakefield and colleagues,34 and titled “Ileal-Lymphoid-Nodular Hyperplasia, Non-specific Colitis, and Pervasive Developmental Disorder in Children.” This Wakefield et al article34 reported a relationship between a supposed gastrointestinal inflammation that followed the childhood measles, mumps, and rubella immunization and the development of autistic symptomatology. The Wakefield et al34 report triggered an antivaccination movement that has resulted in a number of epidemic outbreaks of preventable infectious diseases in Europe and America, endangering the lives of many children.35,36 On February 6, 2010, The Lancet published a retraction of the article.37 However, up to that time the Wakefield et al34 article could have been assigned a scientific worth based on a Thomson Reuters Impact Factor value ranging (Figure 2) from 10.197 to 33.633 (a nearly 230% difference), which would have meant that by numerical ranking the Wakefield et al34 article would be valued at its lowest as having 9 times greater scientific worth than the Roach et al32 article (based on comparison of the 2000 Thomson Reuters Impact Factor values for Journal of Child Neurology and for The Lancet) to a highest figure of about 20 times greater scientific worth based upon comparison of the Thomson Reuters Impact Factor values for the year 2010, which is the year the Wakefield et al34 article was retracted.37 Of course, anyone bothering to take the time to read the articles would readily recognize that the Roach et al32 contribution has had major importance in fields of neurology, genetics, and oncology, while the Wakefield et al34 report was false and has jeopardized the health and well-being of countless children.35,36 An interesting sidelight is that retracted publications can still potentially contribute to a Thomson Reuters Impact Factor value for a journal.38

caption.p: Thomson Reuters Impact Factor values for The Lancet from the years 1998 to 2010 (data from Institute for Scientific Information and Thomson Reuters publications including Journal Citation Reports).

body.p:
This example highlights just one aspect of the problem of allowing scientific worth to be determined by numbers generated in indices such as the Thomson Reuters Impact Factor.17
–20,24,25,39
–44 Another concern with any of these ranking indices is the possibility for manipulation. Unfortunately, to assure a high Thomson Reuters Impact Factor value there is a great deal of gamesmanship necessary from editors and publishers, something that has been well-documented in the past.25,45
–50 Of course, successful gamesmanship necessitates not being caught. Unfortunately, with no specific rules provided by Thomson Reuters, a small journal (Folia Phoniatrica et Logopaedica, which is the official organ of the International Association of Logopedics and Phoniatrics and is published by S. Karger AG, Basel) attempted to test the limits of using self-citation to raise its Thomson Reuters Impact Factor value,51 but was discovered52 and harshly punished53 for the effort. Meanwhile, subtle manipulations continue; for example, as recently as the September 2012 issue (volume 16, number 5) of one journal, there is the following statement on the “Notes To Authors” page: “To increase the visibility of the European Journal of Paediatric Neurology, we ask that your manuscript makes a reference to at least one scientifically relevant and recently published paper in the European Journal of Paediatric Neurology.”

Of greatest importance for individual researchers and clinicians and for the general public is an analysis of the true significance of published materials. The total citations to a given work has been touted as one possible means to determine the value of a publication.54
–62 A problem with such an approach is the method used to record citations.63
–67 The Thomson Reuters Web of Knowledge is one database resource to obtain information about citations, but that database selects out of the approximately 25 000 scholarly journals published world-wide (http://www.stm-assoc.org/2006_09_01_Scientific_Publishing_in_Transition_White_Paper.pdf) only about 12 000 journals as the sources of the citation information. Another database resource for citations is Google Scholar, which includes all publications (including books) that appear online (and thus provides a higher citation number than does the Thomson Reuters Web of Knowledge). The free software program “Publish or Perish” can be used to mine the Google Scholar database for citations.68 –70 However, concerns have been raised about the reliability of the Google Scholar search algorithms used to determine citations.29,65 –67 For the Journal of Child Neurology, the most highly cited articles as of August 2012 from the 2 databases—Thomson Reuters Web of Knowledge and Google Scholar—are shown in Table 1. A metric developed by Jorge E. Hirsch71 (physicist at the University of California, San Diego) based on the total citation counts is the h-index which is determined through the rank ordering of articles according to the number of citations to each article and then finding the article with the lowest number of citations whose rank order equals its number of citations: the rank order number for that article would be the h-index.72 –74 Of course, the h-index can vary depending on which database listing of citations is employed in the analysis.75

body.p: Unfortunately, citation metrics only address the value of the article to those who are also publishing in that same area of study. Bellini134 commented on this problem by describing his 2009 article on nonimmune hydrops fetalis135 published in the prestigious American Journal of Medical Genetics that had only been cited 7 times, while usage data for the online version of the article indicated that it had been downloaded for reading 3167 times. It is likely that information concerning usage of an article would in many instances more appropriately identify the worth of the publication. For the Journal of Child Neurology, usage information can be compared with citation numbers (Tables 1–3), and it is evident that there is a marked discrepancy between usage and citation. Thus, since indices such as the Thomson Reuters Impact Factor values only reflect citations, the usefulness and actual scientific worth of much published material will be greatly underestimated.

body.p:
To counteract the excessive influence of citation metrics such as the Thomson Reuters Impact Factor over the academic community, there have been efforts to develop metrics that assess the electronic usage of articles and journals.136
–139 The United Kingdom Serials Group (UKSG), along with the international initiative COUNTER (Counting Online Usage of Networked Electronic Resources), implemented a study of the feasibility of developing a metric termed the Journal Usage Factor (JUF; http://www.uksg.org/sites/uksg.org/files/FinalReportUsageFactorProject.pdf) which would be a ratio (for a calendar year period) calculated from the total article downloads divided by the total number of articles published online. Interestingly, usage can peak just after publication and then fall off relatively quickly (Figure 3), while citations tend to have a more irregular trend over time. As has been witnessed with the manipulation of Thomson Reuters Impact Factor values, similar manipulation of usage data is possible,139 as discussed by Phil Davis in his blog (web log) The Scholarly Kitchen:
There is always a tendency for an indicator, when accepted broadly, to cease serving as a proxy for some external goal to become that goal itself. The impact factor is no exception, as many scientists believe the extensive use of citation metrics in promotion, grants, and awards has transubstantiated the impact factor from an indicator of quality into quality itself. The US News and World Report College Rankings has had a similar effect on administrators in higher education in spite of the fact that the variables that go into college ranking bears little relationship to the goals of education. If download statistics are a valid indicator of readership now, they will cease to remain so if the JUF is widely implemented. In a system where transparency and accountability are tightly shrouded behind layers of technical and political barriers, there is little holding the Journal Usage Factor from being grossly manipulated for the purposes of its various constituents. When editors and authors change their online behavior in order to raise their usage scores, a download ceases to be an indicator of readership, and becomes something to maximize for its own sake. Articles are downloaded not to be read, but solely to generate a statistic and publishers will simply provide the tools to make this happen. (http://scholarlykitchen.sspnet.org/2011/09/29/journal-usage-factor-think-locally-act-locally/)

caption.p: An example from the Journal of Child Neurology of the variability of usage data (based on usage accessions [x axis] by calendar year [y axis] listed by the HighWire Platform) for selected articles from Tables 1 and 2 by Wang,93 Poling,100 Roach,32 and Hynd.76

body.p: Again, the basic point to be emphasized is that scientific worth cannot and should not be reduced simply to a number value,140 (Figure 4) whether it be the Thomson Reuters Impact Factor, the rankings from any other indices (including Google Scholar and Elsevier SciVerse), or even usage factors. For investigators, administrators, and the general public, the most important concern should be for scientific integrity and quality and the enhancement of knowledge, while ignoring all the contentious issues surrounding journal metrics. Reading and careful study of published materials should be the only method to determine the importance of the scientific contributions of investigators and institutions. Thus, performing sound research and preparing optimal materials for publication must remain the overriding goals of investigators:141 determine article authorship according to the appropriate guidelines; properly articulate in the introduction the question that the study addressed; thoroughly document all methods and case information; carefully describe all results and findings (using clear tables and figures) including any conflicting or negative findings; discuss the importance of the findings along with how the results address the initial question and whether the findings refute or confirm previous studies; prepare a complete list of properly cited bibliographic references; list all author contributions, potential conflicts of interest, financial support, and necessary ethical approvals; and prepare a catchy title and an abstract containing sufficient information that other investigators perusing scientific indices will be enticed to read the published article. Completed manuscripts should be submitted to the most appropriate journal based on that journal’s previously published content and relevance to the field of study without regard to journal metrics. After publication, colleagues and other investigators in the same field can be contacted to make them aware of the publication and to ask for their comments on the work. (There is an Oscar Wilde quotation: “there is only one thing in the world worse than being talked about, and that is not being talked about.”142(p5)) With a work being “talked about,” interested individuals will actually make an effort to thoughtfully read and even possibly cite the work. Thus, an investigator will become known for the quality of his or her work product, and the worshiping of publication metrics will be unnecessary.

caption.p: The problem of trusting number values is nicely illustrated in this DILBERT cartoon that originally appeared on May 8, 2008 (DILBERT © 2008 Scott Adams. Used by permission of UNIVERSAL UCLICK. All rights reserved).
